course_title: Disciplinary Foundations of Tourism, Hospitality and Events

learning_outcomes.description: Discuss the contribution of relevant social science and humanities disciplines to the theoretical knowledge of tourism, hospitality and events.
Draw upon theories and approaches from various disciplines to make informed decisions in real-world tourism, hospitality and event situations.
Incorporate multidisciplinary thinking to solve tourism, hospitality and event problems, by acknowledging and valuing the various approaches taken by different disciplines to the same problem.
Utilise interdisciplinary reasoning to integrate perspectives from multiple disciplines to address complex challenges and capitalise on opportunities.

assessments.task_description:
In the first lecture a Tourism, Hospitality and/or Event related issue will be presented.

This issue will be discussed each week in the tutorials, progressively applying the various disciplines covered in the course to this issue.

To contribute to these discussions, you need to submit TWO (2) one-page discussion papers regarding the issue, over the course of the semester.

For each discussion paper you will need to:

Firstly, undertake research to identify three (3) different key points that are relevant to BOTH the issue and the discipline for that week. Each key point must be ‘new’ to the discussions in the course, and must be from research journal articles, which must be attached to your submission.

Secondly, generate reasoned arguments for why each of these key points are connected to the discussion of the issue and the discipline. These ‘connecting arguments’ must extend beyond the key point and be original, your own reasoning, and written in your own words.  

A one-page template will be provided on Blackboard to assist you in completing this assessment. The three Key Points and the Connecting Arguments MUST fit on the one page (using the formatting of the template). 

The requirements for this task will also be modelled during the initial tutorials so you understand how to complete the task.

You have choice about which disciplines (and therefore which weeks) you wish to select for your submissions. The due date for the first possible submission is in Week Five and the latest possible submission date for your second paper is in Week Ten.

Submissions will be progressive and used to facilitate the tutorial discussions. Therefore, you will need to submit your discussion papers prior to the relevant tutorial.

Each discipline has its own discussion paper due date, and these dates will be provided on the course Blackboard site.

The marking criteria will be provided on the course Blackboard site.

AI STATEMENT

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your paper in word format through Turnitin on the course BlackBoard site, with the required resource pages attached.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this exam, you will need to complete an in-class quiz.

You complete the quiz in the lecture room during the lecture time

You will have 80 minutes to complete the quiz.

The quiz will include 40 Multiple Choice / Answer Questions (MCQs + MAQs).

The quiz will cover all of the topics covered in the course.

You will be provided with further details on the quiz during the semester.

AI STATEMENT

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This Final Exam assessment item requires you to review a journal article in the area of tourism, hospitality and/or events, which will be provided to you in the exam.

The research presented in the article will have used an inter-disciplinary approach that combined two disciplines that were covered in this course this semester.

The article review questions will require you to:

  1. determine the research problem, key literature and methodology,
  2. evaluate the research and assess the contribution of each discipline to the research,
  3. critically assess how using this ‘inter-disciplinary approach’ created real-world outcomes, and
  4. critically evaluate the research, based on the broader course learnings, including: what aspects of the real-world problem have not been addressed in this research? and how might incorporating other disciplinary approaches provide more holistic, comprehensive and equitable solutions?

More details about this assessment task will be provided on the course Blackboard site, and discussed in the final lectures and tutorials.

AI Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction

The week one lecture is an introduction to this course and how it aligns with your decision to enrol in this Masters program.

It will cover both practical aspects, such as the textbook and an overview of the assessment tasks, alongside the course foundations, such as What is a discipline? and Why are different disciplines relevant for tourism, hospitality and events? 

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction The week one lecture is an introduction to this course and how it aligns with your decision to enrol in this Masters program. It will cover both practical aspects, such as the textbook and an overview of the assessment tasks, alongside the course foundations, such as What is a discipline? and Why are different disciplines relevant for tourism, hospitality and events?

learning_activities.topic:
Disciplines & Academic Research

The lecture in week two will provide the foundation for your 'Disciplines journey' this semester, including: What are the Social Sciences? What are the Humanities? What is the difference between multi-disciplinary and inter-disciplinary? How is academic research presented? and Why does all this matter for the real-world opportunities and issues across tourism, hospitality and events?

This lecture will also provide details on the first assessment task - the Discussion Papers, which align with your ‘multi-disciplinary’ tutorials.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Disciplines & Academic Research The lecture in week two will provide the foundation for your 'Disciplines journey' this semester, including: What are the Social Sciences? What are the Humanities? What is the difference between multi-disciplinary and inter-disciplinary? How is academic research presented? and Why does all this matter for the real-world opportunities and issues across tourism, hospitality and events? This lecture will also provide details on the first assessment task - the Discussion Papers, which align with your ‘multi-disciplinary’ tutorials.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial Plan: 'One Issue - One Disciplinary Approach'

This first tutorial will provide an opportunity for everyone to get to know each other better.

Then we will discuss the plan for the tutorial activities this semester.

This will highlight how the discipline that is covered in the lecture (e.g. Geography in Week 4), is then the discipline for the Discussion Paper due the following week (i.e. during Week 5), which is then the focus of the next tutorial (i.e. in Week 6).

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial Plan: 'One Issue - One Disciplinary Approach' This first tutorial will provide an opportunity for everyone to get to know each other better. Then we will discuss the plan for the tutorial activities this semester. This will highlight how the discipline that is covered in the lecture (e.g. Geography in Week 4), is then the discipline for the Discussion Paper due the following week (i.e. during Week 5), which is then the focus of the next tutorial (i.e. in Week 6).

learning_activities.topic:
Sociology

This week begins your journey through the disciplines, starting with the first discipline of Sociology. This will include an introduction to this discipline - its origins, research focus, key theories/ approaches, and methods, followed by its application to tourism, hospitality, and events.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Sociology This week begins your journey through the disciplines, starting with the first discipline of Sociology. This will include an introduction to this discipline - its origins, research focus, key theories/ approaches, and methods, followed by its application to tourism, hospitality, and events.

learning_activities.topic:
Issue - Ecotourism

As all the Discussion Papers will focus on the 'issue' of Ecotourism, the tutorials will be looking at this same issue each week, but from various disciplinary approaches.

It is therefore important to be clear about 'What is Ecotourism?', and this will be covered in the tutorial and activity this week.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Issue - Ecotourism As all the Discussion Papers will focus on the 'issue' of Ecotourism, the tutorials will be looking at this same issue each week, but from various disciplinary approaches. It is therefore important to be clear about 'What is Ecotourism?', and this will be covered in the tutorial and activity this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Sociology – Guided Practice

The tutorials for this week and next week will focus on the discipline of Sociology which has already been covered in the lecture.

These tutorials are designed to help you learn how to complete your Discussion Papers, which will be on two other disciplines.

In this 'guided practice' tutorial you will work in small groups to 'mark' an example Discussion Paper that we have prepared on Sociology and Ecotourism.

This will firstly, illustrate how undertaking the three steps of the assessment task results in a completed Discussion Paper using the provided template, and secondly, help you understand the marking criteria.  

Learning outcomes: L02, L03

In this 'guided practice' tutorial you will work in small groups to 'mark' an example Discussion Paper that we have prepared on Sociology and Ecotourism. This will firstly, illustrate how undertaking the three steps of the assessment task results in a completed Discussion Paper using the provided template, and secondly, help you understand the marking criteria.

learning_activities.topic:
Sociology – Student Practice

The tutorials for last week and this week will focus on the discipline of Sociology which has already been covered in the lecture.

These tutorials are designed to help you learn how to complete your Discussion Papers, which will be on two other disciplines.

In this 'student practice' tutorial you will work in small groups to identify a 'key point' and create a 'connecting argument' from specific pages in a provided Sociology and Ecotourism 'resource'.

This will firstly, provide an example of a relevant 'resource', and secondly, give you the opportunity to practice presenting a 'key point' appropriately and then take the point further to generate the 'connecting argument'.  

Learning outcomes: L02, L03

This discussion also provides an opportunity to further your understanding of the Discussion Papers task as we review 'key points' and 'connecting arguments' from past student submissions.

learning_activities.topic:
One Issue - Multiple Disciplines (Part One)

The last two lectures consider multi and inter disciplinary approaches.

While each discipline is distinct, as covered thus far in the course, it is also important to understand the ways, and advantages of drawing from multiple disciplines to address challenges across tourism, hospitality and events.

This week, we will consider a real-world 'solution', breaking it down to illustrate the various disciplines that apply to 'parts' of the solution, to highlight the need to consider multiple disciplines when addressing complex issues.

As this 'combining disciplines' approach aligns with the final exam, we will also go through the details of this assessment task in the lecture.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: One Issue - Multiple Disciplines (Part One) The last two lectures consider multi and inter disciplinary approaches. While each discipline is distinct, as covered thus far in the course, it is also important to understand the ways, and advantages of drawing from multiple disciplines to address challenges across tourism, hospitality and events. This week, we will consider a real-world 'solution', breaking it down to illustrate the various disciplines that apply to 'parts' of the solution, to highlight the need to consider multiple disciplines when addressing complex issues. As this 'combining disciplines' approach aligns with the final exam, we will also go through the details of this assessment task in the lecture.

learning_activities.topic:
One Issue - Integrating Disciplines

Following all the individual disciplinary applications to the issue, this tutorial progresses the 'combining disciplines' focus that is the basis for your final exam.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: One Issue - Integrating Disciplines Following all the individual disciplinary applications to the issue, this tutorial progresses the 'combining disciplines' focus that is the basis for your final exam.

learning_activities.topic:
One Issue - Multiple Disciplines (Part Two)

The last two lectures consider multi and inter disciplinary approaches.

While each discipline is distinct, as covered thus far in the course, it is also important to understand the opportunities to integrate disciplines to undertake research that addressed the real-world challenges across tourism, hospitality and events.

In this last lecture, we will consider a research project and how various disciplines informed and contributed to the research design, process, theories, and contributions. This provides an example for the final exam assessment task.

Plus final words - keep in touch!

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: One Issue - Multiple Disciplines (Part Two) The last two lectures consider multi and inter disciplinary approaches. While each discipline is distinct, as covered thus far in the course, it is also important to understand the opportunities to integrate disciplines to undertake research that addressed the real-world challenges across tourism, hospitality and events. In this last lecture, we will consider a research project and how various disciplines informed and contributed to the research design, process, theories, and contributions. This provides an example for the final exam assessment task. Plus final words - keep in touch!

learning_activities.topic:
Final Exam Preparation

This final tutorial will help you prepare for the Final Exam, and will cover three separate aspects:

  1. the Exam details - format, timing, what to bring with you, etc  
  2. the Exam requirement - this ‘content’ links to the tutorial activities over the last three weeks
  3. preparing your ‘one-pager’ to bring with you to the exam – guidance and helpful tips will be provided


Learning outcomes: L02, L04
